softwareEngineering.definition: Software Development Life Cycle - A structured process for planning, creating, testing, and deploying software
softwareEngineering.example: A company building a mobile app follows SDLC phases: planning features, designing UI, coding, testing for bugs, and finally releasing to Google Play Store

softwareEngineering.definition: A flexible software development approach that breaks projects into small, iterative cycles called sprints
softwareEngineering.example: Instead of spending 6 months building an entire e-commerce site, the team releases a basic version in 2 weeks, then adds features weekly based on user feedback

softwareEngineering.definition: An Agile framework where teams work in short sprints with daily meetings to track progress
softwareEngineering.example: A development team has a 15-minute daily standup meeting where each member shares what they did yesterday, what they'll do today, and any blockers they face

softwareEngineering.definition: A sequential software development model where each phase must be completed before the next begins
softwareEngineering.example: Building a banking system where all requirements are gathered first, then design is completed, then coding starts - no going back to change requirements mid-development

softwareEngineering.definition: The process of finding and fixing errors or bugs in code
softwareEngineering.example: A login button doesn't work, so the developer uses console logs and breakpoints to find that the password validation function has a typo

softwareEngineering.definition: A version control system that tracks changes in code and allows multiple developers to collaborate
softwareEngineering.example: Three developers work on the same project - one adds a payment feature, another fixes bugs, and Git merges their code without conflicts

softwareEngineering.definition: Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment - Automated process of testing and deploying code changes
softwareEngineering.example: When a developer pushes code to GitHub, automated tests run, and if they pass, the new version is automatically deployed to the live website

softwareEngineering.definition: Application Programming Interface - A set of rules that allows different software applications to communicate
softwareEngineering.example: A weather app uses Google Maps API to show weather data on a map, and OpenWeather API to get temperature information

softwareEngineering.definition: Unified Modeling Language - A standardized way to visualize software system design using diagrams
softwareEngineering.example: Before coding a hospital management system, developers create UML diagrams showing how patients, doctors, and appointments relate to each other

softwareEngineering.definition: The process of verifying that software works correctly and meets requirements
softwareEngineering.example: Before launching an online exam platform, testers check if students can submit answers, if timers work correctly, and if results are calculated properly

cybersecurity.definition: Converting readable data into coded format to prevent unauthorized access
cybersecurity.example: WhatsApp uses end-to-end encryption so that your messages look like random characters to anyone intercepting them, only the recipient can decode them

cybersecurity.definition: Converting encrypted data back into readable format using a key
cybersecurity.example: When you enter your password on a banking app, it decrypts your encrypted account data so you can view your balance

cybersecurity.definition: Malicious software designed to damage, disrupt, or gain unauthorized access to computer systems
cybersecurity.example: A user downloads a fake PDF file that installs ransomware, locking all their files and demanding payment to unlock them

cybersecurity.definition: A cyber attack where attackers pretend to be trustworthy to steal sensitive information
cybersecurity.example: You receive an email that looks like it's from your bank asking you to click a link and enter your password - it's actually a fake website stealing your credentials

cybersecurity.definition: A hacking method that tries every possible password combination until finding the correct one
cybersecurity.example: A hacker uses software to try millions of password combinations like '0000', '0001', '0002' until they crack a 4-digit PIN

cybersecurity.definition: Two-Factor Authentication - A security process requiring two different verification methods to access an account
cybersecurity.example: After entering your Instagram password, you receive an OTP on your phone that you must also enter to log in

cybersecurity.definition: Legal hacking performed to find security vulnerabilities before malicious hackers exploit them
cybersecurity.example: A company hires a certified ethical hacker to try breaking into their website to identify weak points in their security system

cybersecurity.definition: Simulated cyber attack on a system to evaluate its security
cybersecurity.example: Before launching an e-commerce site, security experts attempt to hack it, steal fake customer data, and break payment systems to find vulnerabilities

cybersecurity.definition: General Data Protection Regulation - EU law protecting user privacy and personal data
cybersecurity.example: Websites now ask for cookie consent and allow users to download or delete their personal data to comply with GDPR

cybersecurity.definition: Legal rules and regulations governing internet use and digital crimes
cybersecurity.example: India's IT Act 2000 makes hacking, spreading computer viruses, and online fraud punishable with fines and imprisonment

emergingTech.definition: Artificial Intelligence - Technology that enables machines to simulate human intelligence and decision-making
emergingTech.example: ChatGPT understands your questions and generates human-like responses, Netflix recommends shows based on what you watch

emergingTech.definition: A subset of AI where computers learn from data without being explicitly programmed
emergingTech.example: Spotify learns your music taste by analyzing what songs you play, skip, or replay, then creates personalized playlists

emergingTech.definition: Advanced ML using neural networks with multiple layers to process complex data
emergingTech.example: Tesla's self-driving cars use deep learning to recognize pedestrians, traffic signs, and other vehicles in real-time

emergingTech.definition: Computing systems inspired by the human brain that recognize patterns in data
emergingTech.example: Face unlock on your phone uses neural networks to learn your facial features and distinguish you from others

emergingTech.definition: A decentralized digital ledger that records transactions across multiple computers securely
emergingTech.example: Bitcoin transactions are recorded on blockchain, making it nearly impossible to alter or fake transaction history

emergingTech.definition: Internet of Things - Network of physical devices connected to the internet, collecting and sharing data
emergingTech.example: Your smart home has IoT devices: lights controlled by voice, refrigerator that orders groceries, and AC that adjusts temperature automatically

emergingTech.definition: Augmented Reality - Technology that overlays digital information onto the real world
emergingTech.example: Pokemon Go shows virtual creatures in your real surroundings through your phone camera, IKEA app lets you see how furniture looks in your room

emergingTech.definition: Virtual Reality - Immersive technology that creates completely digital environments
emergingTech.example: Using a VR headset, medical students practice surgery in a virtual operating room without any real-world risks

emergingTech.definition: Advanced computing using quantum mechanics to process information exponentially faster than traditional computers
emergingTech.example: While a regular computer would take years to crack complex encryption, a quantum computer could potentially do it in minutes

emergingTech.definition: Fifth-generation wireless technology offering ultra-fast internet speeds and low latency
emergingTech.example: With 5G, you can download a full HD movie in seconds, play cloud games without lag, and have smooth video calls even in crowded areas

emergingTech.definition: Processing data near its source rather than sending it to distant cloud servers
emergingTech.example: A smart traffic light processes camera data locally to change signals in real-time, instead of sending video to the cloud and waiting for response

mathematics.definition: Study of mathematical structures that are distinct and separate, used in computer algorithms and logic
mathematics.example: Graph theory (part of discrete math) helps Google Maps find the shortest route between two locations by treating roads as edges and intersections as nodes

mathematics.definition: Mathematical system dealing with true/false values, fundamental to digital circuit design
mathematics.example: When you search 'Python AND programming NOT snake', the search engine uses Boolean logic to find pages about programming Python, excluding results about reptiles

mathematics.definition: Study of vectors, matrices, and linear equations used in graphics and machine learning
mathematics.example: When you rotate or resize an image in Photoshop, linear algebra matrices calculate the new position of every pixel

mathematics.definition: Mathematical study of likelihood and chance of events occurring
mathematics.example: Email spam filters use probability to calculate the chance a message is spam based on words like 'free', 'winner', or 'click here'

mathematics.definition: Science of collecting, analyzing, and interpreting data to make informed decisions
mathematics.example: YouTube uses statistics to show you 'Trending' videos - analyzing view counts, watch time, and engagement across millions of users

mathematics.definition: Mathematical study of continuous change, used in optimization and machine learning
mathematics.example: Netflix uses calculus to optimize video streaming quality - calculating the perfect bitrate based on your internet speed to avoid buffering

mathematics.definition: Step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or completing a task
mathematics.example: Instagram's feed algorithm decides which posts to show first based on your likes, comments, and time spent viewing similar content

mathematics.definition: Mathematical notation describing how algorithm performance changes as input size grows
mathematics.example: Searching for a name in an unsorted list of 1 million contacts is O(n) - it might check all million. In a sorted list with binary search, it's O(log n) - checks only about 20

mathematics.definition: Mathematical study of collections of objects and relationships between them
mathematics.example: Database queries use set theory - 'Find users who are in both Premium subscribers AND active this month' uses the intersection of two sets

mathematics.definition: Study of graphs (networks of connected nodes), used in social networks and routing
mathematics.example: LinkedIn's 'People You May Know' uses graph theory to find connections - if you know A and B, and they both know C, the algorithm suggests C to you

indianTech.definition: India's unique 12-digit biometric identification system for residents
indianTech.example: You can open a bank account, get a SIM card, file income tax, or verify identity for government services using your Aadhaar number

indianTech.definition: Unified Payments Interface - India's instant real-time payment system for mobile transactions
indianTech.example: You can pay for groceries by scanning a QR code with Google Pay, PhonePe, or Paytm - money transfers instantly from your bank account

indianTech.definition: Government initiative to transform India into a digitally empowered society
indianTech.example: Village residents can now access government certificates, apply for schemes, and make digital payments through Common Service Centers without traveling to cities

indianTech.definition: Government program to support and promote entrepreneurship and innovation
indianTech.example: A college student with a tech startup idea can register under Startup India to get tax benefits, funding support, and mentorship from industry experts

indianTech.definition: National Programme on Technology Enhanced Learning - Free online courses by IIT/IISc professors
indianTech.example: Engineering students across India take NPTEL courses on Data Structures, Machine Learning, or Web Development for free, earning certificates recognized by companies
